author: {'steamid': '76561198022221037', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 65, 'playtime_forever': 466, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 454, 'last_played': 1614768383}
review:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qfGY2B4T2Kw&feature=youtu.be

http://youtu.be/xh1cat703ig

In Take on Mars, werdet Ihr zum Erkunder, Forscher und vielleicht zum Raumfahrtexperten.
Schon in dieser frühen Early Access Phase steckt das Spiel voller Möglichkeiten, mit denen
man die Zeit verbringen kann.


Im Karrieremodus müsst Ihr Euch allerdings erst einmal hocharbeiten. Beginnend mit einer kleinen Sonde,
die Ihr auf dem Mars (oder auch andere Himmelskörper) absetzt, könnt ihr erste Daten sammeln.
Man hat ein kleines Budget, welches verwendet wird um die kleinen Sonden für die Missionen
zu bezahlen. Jedoch erhält man bei erfolgreichen Missionen, auch genügend Geld um neue Dinge zu
erforschen.


Da kommen wir zum nächsten Punkt. Dem "Tech Tree". In dem zu anfangs etwas unübersichtlichen Baum,
könnt Ihr verschiedene Bereiche für die in zukunft geplanten Missionen erforschen. Das kostet einiges an Geld
und dauert auch eine gewisse Zeit, bis diese fertig erforscht werden. (Man kann die Zeit im Spiel beschleunigen,
einige Dinge brauchen zum Beispiel 20 Std. Echtzeit oder mehr...)

Auf der linken Seite des "Tech Trees" seht ihr eine Liste an verschiedenen Sachen, für Rover, Lander,
Forschungsequipment usw. Einmal auf eines der Objekte geklickt, wird Euch mit blauen Linien angezeigt
welche der Sachen Ihr erforschen müsst und das jenige freizuschalten.


Mit den erforschten "Teilen" könnt Ihr auch im Labor, die Sonden verbessern oder auch komplett eigene
bauen. {Es gibt nicht die Möglichkeit alles komplett selber zu bauen.} Das Spiel bietet Euch jedoch
verschiedene Grundgerüste, an denen Ihr Roboter-Arme, Kameras, Batterien, Solarpanele oder
ähnliches anbringen könnt. Anschliessend könnt Ihr die nun gebaute Sonde, oder den Rover direkt zum Mars
schicken, oder Ihr testet diese auf dem Testgelände. (Würde ich bei komplexeren Dingen empfehlen)


Das Spiel sieht zu dem noch super aus und läuft schon sehr rund. Bisher hatte ich keine Abstürze oder
freezes.

Ich kann dieses kleine (für mich) Meisterwerk, schon jetzt empfehlen. Trotz der noch frühen Phase.
Es macht einfach sehr viel Spaß und jeder der sich ein wenig für unser Universum, oder das Sonnensystem
interessiert, der kann es sich gern mal anschauen.

MfG ALP

author: {'steamid': '76561198029644676', 'num_games_owned': 159, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 531, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 531, 'last_played': 1457675439}
review:
Je ne comprends pas l’intérêt de ce jeu, il manque énormément d'interactions, tout est automatique (sauf le pilotage de rover d'une lenteur.... d'un réalisme sans nom). L'arbre des recherches est très peu fourni, avec une progression verticale tout ce qu'il y a de plus redondant, sans intérêt, vous n'avez pas vraiment le choix quant aux connaissances à acquérir, car les différentes missions proposées vous demanderont souvent de débloquer telle ou telle compétence obligatoirement. Pas vraiment de choix dans le budget non plus, il vous faudra automatiquement des équipements précis pour vos missions, pas le choix du site de largage non plus, les sites sont choisie par..... quelqu'un d'autre, surement le stagiaire. Vous pouvez aussi vous gratter sur la configuration et la construction des sondes et autres rovers, tout a un châssis fix et des modèles de pose ultra restrictifs, oubliez vos élans créatifs.

Depuis peu, le jeu a pris un virage à 7000°, en effet, les développeurs de ce truc ont eu le sentiment que l’intérêt d'un tel jeu était, comment dire, foutrement sans intérêt et ont décidé de changer d'orientation, je vous laisse deviner pour quoi, de la survie bien entendu, c'est tellement à la mode. Maintenant vous jouerez un astronaute sur mars qui doit se démerder à la manière d'un Space Engineers mais sans les avantages de ce dernier, les interactions sont ultra limité, la zone de jeu peu intéressante (c'est mars quoi) et le moteur physique est complètement dans les choux. Bref il n'y a pas grand-chose à faire dans ce jeu.

Si vous aimez l'espace,
si vous aimez construire des fusées, des rovers, des modules lunaires de A a Z,
si vous aimez les piloter, calculer leurs trajectoires,
les voir s'enfoncer dans l’immensité de l'espace commandes en main,
si vous aimez les très grands open world,
si vous aimez réparer votre moteur principal en plein espace, en EVAT et en mode Gravity,
Alors, achetez Kerbal Space Program et téléchargez son mod Realism Overhaul via Ckan.

Vous allez vous éclater, ce qui n'est pas le cas sur Take On Mars, dommage, j'aime l'espace.

author: {'steamid': '76561197965028239', 'num_games_owned': 229, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 2081, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1771, 'last_played': 1460585959}
review:
Well what a hidden gem this game was. I nearly didn't bother buying it as I was put off by the association implied by "Take On", as I wasted money on the godawful Take On Helicopters (Sorry, but it is).
Anyhoo, this game, even it's its early access form, is one of the most original, unique and strangely engrossing games I have come across. The only other game that has really attempted something similar is Mars Colony Challenger, and that isn't too bad considering it's a one man job. TOM takes it to the next level, with great visuals, a wealth of information, atmosphere and good old relaxing gameplay.
The single player Space Program game will not be for everyone. In it's early stages it basically consists of launching increasingly advanced probes and landers on Mars to gather scientific information. If you complete a mission you get extra cash and funding, used to create or research more advanced tech such as Rovers etc. It can get a little repetitive but you will learn more about Mars in a couple of hours of gameplay than you thought possible. Some of the missions are quite challenging, and instructions can be a tad unlear, but when you get it right, it's satisfying. When controlling landers and rovers there is a real sense of reality about it. 
The second stage of the single player is the manned mission. Where you have to survive on Mars while conducting missions etc. You need to mine resources, build your base, so on and so forth.I have not started this stage yet, but I am assuming it somewhat similar to multiplayer. 
Multiplayer is where the game shines like a Martian sunrise, but it's also a bit of a dust storm at present too. The basic premise is players work together to build their colony. It is in it's initial release, so expect more depth to be added, such as the survival mechanics and resource gathering being required. When it is fully fleshed out, you will have one incredible sim which will encourage some great cooperative gameplay. Multiplayer games can also be saved to all clients, not just the host. Allowing for continuing session play on your favorite base/project.
Multiplayer is flawed though. A severe lack of server commands for the host is just one problem. There is no way to kick players, and there are some idiots out there. They will spoil all your hard work, build crap you dont need, drive off in vehicles, change what you have constructed or just be general pains in the arse. As well as a kick/ban function, the game lacks any means to remove items you dont require or make by accident. Often your well planned base can end up looking like a junkyard. Also, the object count can seriously impact framerates, so the less rubbish around, the better. There is also no way for the host to "lock" items in place. Whixh means that any idiot with a tool can tear things apart or adjust constructions that you have spent time building to your own design. It should be possible to disable the tool function for other players as seen fit, or to mark a construction as "locked" or "complete" etc so that no changes can be made without the host consent. As far as I am concerned, the host is the guy in charge of the mission, and should have the controls to achieve that.
All that being said, multiplayer is freaking awesome when you get a couple of good players. A random player joined my game and we spent hours constructing a base complete with control center, observatory and raised landing pad. We had an encircling balcony on the control center which was just missing some patio furniture. It was very satisfying, especially as we built most of it in the dark and didn't really know what we had accomplished until sunrise. Unfortunately the game then became somewhat unplayable due to the large number of objects. We felt like we were walking in slow motion and it took so long to accomplish anything else that we called it a day. Hopefully this issue will be addressed and improved by the Devs. Multiplayer is still in it's intitial release of course, but it's a good initial release.
The Dev team is very active, and take a lot of interest in their players. They obviously have a passion for this game that I am certain will see it constantly improving all the way to full release. They are not trying to milk cash from an early access game like some, and the price you pay for the game at present is more than worth it.

All in all I am rating this a 9/10. Innovative, interesting and well supported. Buy it! Just buy it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198015341353', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 104, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 67, 'last_played': 1453399443}
review:
I've now spent over an hour trying to get into this game, but it's extremely unforgiving. 

You start the game off with $3 million. Research can easily bring that down to $500 thousand. Basic probe missions net you $150 thousand, but you *need* at least $50 to start these.

Spent 30 minutes surveying Mars with probes these basic probes that I cannot control, taking pictures of the land. Ran out of money conducting research, and I could not afford to fund another mission (game over).

Spent the next 30 minutes restarting the game. Surveyed all of Mars and built up my funds, so I researched a controllable zero-G probe. Think of a quadcopter, for space. This was obviously more fun to survey things with, as you actually got to do something. Only problem is that if you are too sporadic with your in-flight maneuvers, then components break. Components break, you lose control of your $1 million probe (yes, these ones cost $1 million). Good news is that if you don't screw up, you net $1.5 million. Otherwise, you're pretty much screwed.

I spun my zero-G probe too fast, lost control of it, and went from $1.9 million to $900 thousand. Really really frustrating spending a half hour getting to this comfortable point, just to have it all fall apart because I held the Up-Arrow too long. It was then not worth the time to try and recover the funds.

I would love to continue this game, but the knowledge that the game assumes you have about playing it is too much to learn without hours worth of trial and error, which means restarting your game multiple times, which means taking at least 30 minutes to an hour or more to get back to where you were.

I DO recommend this game, I just don't know enough not to continue to get frustrated by it, so beware.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040601143', 'num_games_owned': 207, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 664, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 581, 'last_played': 1422555502}
review:
Save Game #1:
Preso dalla foga, sbrigo velocemente tutte le missioni in cui si richiedono sonde e Lander per poter finalmente ricercare il Rover, infischiandomene di comprendere il benché minimo funzionamento di come si gestisce un budget di questo genere.
Una volta sbloccato lo small Rover, non ho più un centesimo in tasca e non posso proseguire nel gioco.

Save Game #2:
Giunto di nuovo al Rover, intraprendo la prima vera missione su Marte.
Inserisco il comando "FORWARD 2 KM", dimenticando di togliere dall'HUB gli indicatori relativi alle altre missioni. 
Vago per quattro ore reali verso un obiettivo che non fa parte della missione e non ho idea di come si faccia ad annullare il comando. 
Enormi massi polverosi fanno cambiare direzione al Rover diverse volte.
La batteria si esaurisce e il "Garibaldi I" si spegne per sempre.
Il rumore delicato e monotono delle ruote robotiche lascia il posto al silenzio del deserto marziano, immerso in un'atmosfera di pace e nulla che è paragonabile soltanto al vuoto che avverto dentro al mio cuore incompetente dopo una tale disfatta.

10/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198018918162', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 3207, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1117, 'last_played': 1479414638}
review:
Das Spiel ist der Hammer wenn man auf eine Mischung aus Space Engeneers und Kerbal steht.
Man kann basteln, erforschen und erkunden. Alles wie und wo man möchte. Zumindest im Multiplayer. Andere Modi sind ja Missionen.
Das Potenzial ist wirklich enorm. Ich freue mich drauf wenn die extrahierten Ressourcen den kompletten Umfang haben.
Kohlenwasserstoff kann man ja schon Kohle und Wasser trennen.
Auch bin ich gespannt wie es wird wenn die Selbstversorgung bzw. man dan Char am leben halten muss mit Nahrung u.s.w.
Natürlich müssen noch viel mehr Bauteile kommen. 
Ich hoffe das das Spiel bis zum Ende etwickelt wird bzw. das Geld dafür da ist.

Habe extra mein aller ersten Eindruck stehen lassen.
Jetzt wo ich die neue Erweiterung angespielt habe und mich sehr über die Pflanzen und das neue Fahrzeug gefreut habe ist leider erneut nach 1 Stunde flaute eingetreten.
Man kann die Kapsel nicht bestromen und als Basis nutzen...das bauen ist meiner Meinung nach immer noch viel zu unbequem und unnötig komplieziert. 
Das sollte viel schneller gehen.

Die Bekanntgabe des Final finde ich sehr gewagt. 
Wie gesagt es gibt viele einzelne Happen aber noch lange kein Menü.

author: {'steamid': '76561198024313605', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 1631, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 398, 'last_played': 1515374046}
review: If you want to murder your friends on mars, or shoot space aliens, move along.... but if your an intelligent, patient, and mature person who wants to survive on mars, then buy this because its amazing

author: {'steamid': '76561197998701258', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 119, 'playtime_forever': 1092, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 486, 'last_played': 1516413722}
review:
I really wanted to like this one, and it's coming along in leaps and bounds, but as it stands at the moment, there's not a great deal there.

The base game involves launching probes at map locations and watching them land. You'll do a lot of that until you can build up enough money to start doing more interesting things with rovers and landers.

The recent addition of the multi-player component adds a massive amount more to the game, giving you the ability to build your own little mars base and keep yourself alive... but it's definitely in its infancy.

Graphically it's lovely.  Gameplay... early stages.

If you like the idea of exploring Mars, and quite fancy the thought of building your own base there, then DEFINITELY keep this one bookmarked. However, I'd recommend waiting until there's a bit more development before getting too excited.

It has a lot of potential, and I'll recommend it on the strength of that alone.

author: {'steamid': '76561198024478413', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 213, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 213, 'last_played': 1419967673}
review: I know I'm going against the majority here, who seem to have enjoyed the game, but I was expecting something quite different. I realize it's an early access title but the fundamentals aren't really there. The physics engine is jittery and jiggly almost to a comic degree and the career mode is pure grind that will have you do the same thing over and over again to do a different thing over and over again. Here's hoping as least some of this changes before release. Details: http://youtu.be/VwKfVaEn7K4

author: {'steamid': '76561198053458049', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 44, 'playtime_forever': 1669, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 682, 'last_played': 1444142105}
review:
Makes you feel like Jebediah!

Ci sono parecchi bug essendo un early access, ma è comunque già godibile. Sembra molto vario, si passa da teleguidare il Pathfinder a costruirsi (a mano!) una stazione lunare, sono molto curioso di proseguire e soprattutto di vedere come sarà il gioco completo.

Cosa molto importante, questo gioco è complementare a Kerbal Space Program. Quello che ha uno manca all'altro, praticamente senza sovrapposizioni.

...e scendere dal lem e lasciare le proprie imponte sulla Luna, vedere la terra in lontananza, correre sul rover quando l'O2 inizia a calare... 10/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198072380091', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 51, 'playtime_forever': 283, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 264, 'last_played': 1424208450}
review:
While the basic idea of this game is terrific, the execution is lacking in major ways. I really hope the developers continue to shape the main aspects of this game, as the concept does have a lot of potential.

The big issue in my point of view, and why I'd not recommend it at this time:

Very linear gameplay, for an exploration game it lacks the "open world" feeling. This is immediately evident when you execute your first mission, you can see a rectangular plane of mars, your mission area, floating in the void of space, in the early descent phase.

The career part is mission based, so instead of conducting free-form exploration, the player launches a vehicle to perform a very specific set of tasks.

The first ten missions you will launch for example consist of nothing more than selecting a point on the map, launch the vehicle, look at the descent phase, wait for the "exploration accomplished" info to pop up, and immediately disconnect from the vehicle as the mission is done even before you touch down.

The next couple of missions involve you actually waiting until touchdown, activate one instrument, and disconnect.

The vehicle design suffers from similar issues, it is just way too linear. You basically select a chassis, stick some instruments in predefined slots, without any real freedom in design.


I really want to like this game, and in fact I do not regret investing the 15 bucks as it might get somewhere someday, but at this time there simply does not come up any real fun playing this.

author: {'steamid': '76561198075828399', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 200, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 146, 'last_played': 1446571474}
review:
If you enjoy Kerbal Space program and expect same thing to this, DON'T buy it.
Graphic and sound is best, but things you can is just seeing probe's landing and other small things.
There is completely NO joy of building probes and moving it around like KSP.

I say again graphic and sound is impressive. this is true, but I enjoyed this game for first 10-20 mins.
I wasted money.

author: {'steamid': '76561198039602231', 'num_games_owned': 1281, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 530, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 461, 'last_played': 1466815484}
review:
Это не песочница, это не симулятор. Пока это сырая аркада с элементами симулятора.

Плюсы
 - Графика
 - Идея
 - Дизайн

Минусы:
1. Наука. Науки в игре нет. Можно сколько угодно фотографировать камешки, но если это не прописано в мисси, то толку с этого 0 (см. п. 2). И да, в игре нет такого понятия как научные очки (как в KSP) - все делается исключительно только за бабло.
2. Миссии. Абсолютно статичны. Вы должны сфотографить именно эту панораму, просверлить именно этот камешек, доехать именно до этой точки, собрать газ именно в этом месте и никак иначе. Высадились не в том месте - мне вас жаль. Хотите поисследовать окруающую местность - забудтье, следуйте строго по вейтпоинтам. Установили супер-пупер навроченное оборудование - зря старались, для этой миссии достаточно было приземлиться, ну или же прикрепляйте аппарат к другой мисии и добирайтесь до новой миссии за 100500 км. Где здесь логика - мне не очень понятно. Космонавтике вообще свойственны внештатные ситуации, которые порой открывали новые возможности. Здесь же отстувует такое понятие как условно выполненное задание - либо ты сфотографируешь именно этот камушек, да-да-да, именно этот и никакой другой, либо задание не будет засчитано. Заниматься свободным поиском здесь не положено.
3. Дерево технологий. Оно неплохое. Но само исследование новых технологий настораживает. Во-первых, возникает такое ощущение, что все технологии изучает суперкомпьютер - время исследования измеряется часами: слабо разработать ядерную бомбу за 4 часа? Во-вторых, марсианские миссии и дерево технологий существуют в параллельных мирах, единственная связь между которыми - это бабло. Я уже говорил, что здесь все делается исключительно за бабло?
4. Конструирования. Прострора для творчества мягко говоря маловато. Выбираем шасси, навешиваем на него пару датчиков и манипуляторов - все Hi-tech устройство готово. И не удивлятейсь если обнаружите вещи, которые вы не проектировали. Боле того, вариантов конфигурации не особо много, стандартные пресеты все перекрывают. Забудте про полет творчества как это было в KSP. И да спроектировав аппарат, вы обнаружите, что он спускается со здоровенной такой елдой, кторую за вас спроектировали разработчики этой игры, а на вашем устройстве появятся камеры, которые вы не устанавливали.
5. Гринд. Да-да, именно он, родимый. Завалите Марс одноразовыми зондами, что бы потом завалить его роверами, что бы потом завалить его... Логика опять уходит покурить - с одной стороны все делается за бабло, с другой стороны "спонсоры" позволяют тратить драгоценное бабло замусоривая Марс, после чего дают еще больше бабла. 
Солько американцы запустили космических аппаратов по Лунной программе окромя "Аполлонов"? 9 "Рейнджеров", 5 "Луна-орбитер", 7 "Сервейер" и 11 "Пионеров". Да-да, те самые "Пионеры", которые потом исследовали Юпитер и Стаурн (см. п.2 - Миссии). И это за 10 лет. Много? Тогда готовьтесь теперь запустить зонды вообще без оборудования просто в промышленных масштабах, только ради бабла.
6. Моделирование технических систем. Оно отсутсвует. Одни аппараты ну никак не согласны запускаться без отдельной антенны, другие же отлично проживут и без них (видимо в них встроенно какое- тайное устройство). Никаких задержек сигналов, никаких головоломок с рапсространением радиоволн (как в моде RemoTech на KSP), никакой инфраструктуры в принципе здесь нет. А это не только связь, но и вычислительные системы, регуляторы и прочее. Не замечено и влияние окружающей среды, нет никаких отказов, даже намеренно сломать что либо достаточно сложно. Одним словом - сплошная казуальщина.
7. Спутники. Их нет.
8. Программирование. Есть возможность запрограммировать аппарат выполнять очередь задач, но нет никаких инстурментов для планирования, а учитывая, что программирование тут находится в самой зачаточной стадии, то это однозначный феил.
9. Физика. Ставьте её сразу на максимум, иначе ваши творения будут улетать в параллельную вселенную.
10. Баги. Пламя от двигателей выходит совершенно не оттуда, откуда должно, например, оно может выходить несколькими метрами выше, чем находится  сам аппарат. Игра может вылететь...например, после того, как вы битай час ехали до чередного вейтпоинта. Учитывая, что игра в раннем доступе почти полтора года.....

Вывод: Настоятельной не советую. YOBA-игра пытается мимкрировать под что-то серьезное и получается это у неё плохо. Пустая трата времени и денег. Лучше скайчайте бесплатный Orbiter или купите KSP.

author: {'steamid': '76561198083830254', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 5217, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2163, 'last_played': 1565501185}
review: Take On Mars is by far the best space simulation game I have ever played. There are many building and customization options, large maps, and even a singleplayer space program mode where you can advance your space program through the tech tree, landing black and white picture probes at first, but with work, you can land high tech large rovers with atmosphere processors, color cameras, and drills. The game also has a cool feature called the Mars Encyclopedia, a book in which you unlock pictures and paragraphs about Mars by completing missions. You can also build your own levels that you can play for custom missions. Another amazing feature of Take On Mars is the multiplayer feature. You can literally set up a server that is easy to connect to anywere in the world in just two clicks. Also, the develepors listen to the community's suggestions well, and they update the game often. If you are interested in an awesome space simulation game, Take On Mars is the game for you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198008521668', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 51, 'playtime_forever': 830, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 793, 'last_played': 1489028551}
review:
Fan de KSP , je me suis décidé à sauter le pas pour Take On Mars.

Globalement, le Principe de programme spatial est plutot sympa mais la realisation peche.
Le Jeu est en early acces certes , mais reste tres instable.

L'arbre des technologies est assez coherent et donne envie d'engranger du cash pour le develloper.

Il vous faudra jouer serrer avec votre budget pour concevoir le rover le plus économe et polyvalent possible.Mais dieu que c'est mou et linéaire..

Des petites animations aurait gagnées a renforcer l'immersion qui fait cruellement défaut,
concretement vous creez votre lander / probe et paf il est instantanement en rentree atmospherique.Il ne vous reste plus qu'a croiser les doigts qu'un bug ne vous éclate pas votre precieux robot contre le sol martien...voila pour la partie Robot.

Concernant la partie survival et colonisation le jeu reprends des couleurs
Les scénarios sont assez sympa notamment sur la lune , mais l'ergonomie de construction est peu intuitive.

Bref  avis mitigé pour le temps passé dessus mais pas mal d'espoir
Ca reste une early acces donc a suivre...

author: {'steamid': '76561197989058837', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 86, 'playtime_forever': 341, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 224, 'last_played': 1601908451}
review:
NOTE: This review does not apply to the multiplayer aspect of the game.

This game sounds very attractive on paper, Sadly right now it's little more than a thematic tech demo. From a technical standpoint it's a great piece of software, but it's simply not engaging.

Usually games, even though they might be hardcore (Orbiter, Dwarf Fortress, even KSP) make you feel rewarded when you achieve your goals. Even when those goals are self-imposed, you have a sense of achievement.

Imagine setting out to land on Eve and take off in KSP, or gather enough diamonds in Minecraft to make yourself a full set of armor. The game knows nothing about your objectives, but it has built-in impedements that make you feel you are working for something, and the game is balanced in such a way that, the more crazy your objective, the more difficulties you will encounter. And besides that, you have different tools at your disposal, in a way that you feel you have the freedom to attack the problem from different angles.

Take on Mars feels like you are just following a fixed list of steps (missions are exactly that actually) in order to put a checkbox in your to-do list and move to the next item. You have very little room to improvise or be clever about how you approach the missions, and the hardships you encounter are just not interesting nor really challenging.

As someone who has spent hundreds of hours playing the hardcore space flight sim Orbiter I would never have imagined a game like this would bore me. But sadly it does.

The research tree is very rich, and the mechanics of building and deploying vehicles are rock solid. Perhaps the problem is the game is too linear for a sandbox.

I'd wait until the developers fulfilled their vision for the game completely before buying it. Wait and see mode.

author: {'steamid': '76561198050684393', 'num_games_owned': 191, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 7882, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3800, 'last_played': 1697212400}
review:
This is a great game, if you’re into this kind of stuff. Otherwise I guess you’ll hate it, which of course would make you a heartless monster.
TakeOn Mars certainly is no GTA Mars. Getting to your next target can and will require prolonged use of your W-key as your rover crawls over the martian surface at a snail’s pace. But hey, you’re rewarded with actual education! Now isn’t that fun!?
While you progress through the missions the built-in encyclopedia presents you with tons of actual facts about Mars which you could also find on Wikipedia without having to carefully drive your rover down some crater wall first.
So if you feel “ready” for a “more or less accurate” simulation of Mars exploration this game may be for you as well. Otherwise I guess it’s more likely you’ll be bored to death and back.

Seriously, it’s awesome!

author: {'steamid': '76561198085851092', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 3583, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1620, 'last_played': 1420550344}
review:
Итак, здесь я кратко поясню за игру.

Если вы любите драйвовые погони, зеленых человечков, перестрелки бластерами и прочую голивудщину, то покупать игру не нужно, она Вам покажется скучной, унылой, однообразной.

Если же вам нравится неспеша кататься по кратерам Марса, аккуратно и бережно обруливать одинокие камешки, фотографировать валуны, обстреливать их ренгеновскими лучами, брать образцы их породы, то я сразу могу сказать- эта игра для Вас. 

Фичи (Особенности) игры

[list]
  [*] [b]Исследуйте поверхность Красной планеты.[/b] В игре вы встретите множество типов научного оборудования: сверла для взятия проб, детекторы альбедо, анализаторы газа. Открывать вы их будете спускаясь по технологическому древу
  [*] [b]Многообразие аппаратов.[/b] Открывая все новые и новые технологии вы юудете так же открывать и новые "скелеты" аппаратов. Здесь будет и маленький лендер, и и маленький ровер, и большой ровер. Каждый "скелет" обладает своими характеристикаи: как скоростью, так и количеством научного оборудования на борту
  [*] [b]Мультиплеер.[/b] Надоело созерцание одиноких безжизенных железяк? Так зайдите в мультиплее и поиграйте друзьями! Вы получите возможность побродить по марсианской базе, покататься на машинах под увлекательыне беседы.
[/list]

[b]Небольшие советы для начинающих[/b]

Сперва бывает трудно копить деньги, миссий становится все меньше, а маленькие роверы мало чего могут. В таком случае просто исследуйте Zero-G Probe и изучайте Фобос! на нем можно крайне быстро "скакать" от цели к цели, набивая карманы зелеными бумажками.

author: {'steamid': '76561198043607086', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 3519, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1562, 'last_played': 1535332277}
review:
Jogo excelente, extremamente simulado, mesmo em versão de acesso antecipado e ainda cheio de ideias futuras.
A qualidade gráfica do jogo é excepcional e ainda com diversas opções para deixar a seu gosto.
A gama de equipamentos e interações com eles é muito boa e muito bem feita.
A qualidade das texturas, a modelagem, a geometria, a Física e o próprio ambiente do jogo é sem igual, deram um foco aos detalhes na medida certa, possuindo até mesmo o veiculo, partes independentes com danos somente naquela peça.
Diversos tipos de missões pra cada tipo de veículo que construir tendo até diversidades da ambientação, já que você é quem escolhe onde e quando enviar tal veiculo e sendo assim exposto ao ambiente noturno e até mesmos se encuralando em tempestades de areia.
Excelente campanha contando a história da exploração em Marte, podendo fazer as pesquisas para melhorar os veiculos e mandá-los para explorar em diversos tipso de missões.
O multiplayer, apesar de estar no começo do desenvolvimento já é bastante interativo e cheio de implementos. Pode também juntar com seus amigos e construir uma grande base para talvez, futuras explorações cooperativas.

author: {'steamid': '76561197982601795', 'num_games_owned': 363, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 861, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 861, 'last_played': 1410417232}
review:
The latest update has completely and utterly broken this game, and the developer seems to be more interested in adding stuff instead of getting what already exists to work properly.  Previous versions worked (rather well, I might add).  Here's the rundown of what's going wrong:

First of all, the career mode is an exercise in tedium and in no way reflects how the exploration of Mars actually played out.  Technologies are far too expensive, requiring players to repeat the same mission type (probe exploration; basically dropping a camera-equipped dumbell onto the surface) to get your first meagre stream of "revenue".  While you start with a fair bit of cash, you burn through it quickly researching the technologies needed to build your first small lander.  The only problem with your first lander is that many of the "major goals" involve taking photographs in multiple directions; something your small lander is categorically incapable of doing, even if you research the technologies needed for the camera mast (the component needed to take panoramic shots).  

Secondly, the method of controlling various instruments, and in fact the whole keymap for TKOM, appears to be based in fallacy; nothing works at all!  I can't get robotic arms to do anything, and I am unable to switch what the primary and secondary controls actually control anything other than the retro thrusters.  Trying to edit the keymap just ends in frustration too - it won't let you add controls that are assigned to other functions, even if those other functions are not active or even possible.  You can't, for example, delete the thruster controls in Lander mode and re-map them to the same key because the game warns you that the control is shared with the movement keys for Human mode - YES I KNOW THEY'RE THE SAME CONTROL BUT THERE ISN'T A HUMAN ANYWHERE NEAR MARS, AND AT THE RATE WE'RE GOING, THERE WON'T EVER BE ONE EITHER!  And don't even get me started on joystick support - if you have anything except for an XBox controller, you're totally and utterly boned, because you can't remap the axes and you can't set deadzones either.  Normally, I wouldn't be too irritated by this, but the developer, Dram (yes, I'm calling you out by name), has been posting all over the Steam support forum for this game, promising proper joystick support for the better part of 18 months now, and we've got nothing to show for it.

There are other little irritations too; automatic flight mode is janky as all hell; landers swoop down low, then skim the surface in a rather uneconomical way, then when they approach their destination they scream up to a few dozen meters, then slowly return to land.  That is, if they don't get caught in an endless hover loop twenty meters from the target.  So you click off automatic mode and try to land the thing manually - good luck with THAT.  A lack of actual tutorials is an impediment to the game as well - all you get are a series of unhelpful videos.

In short, if you want go go explore Mars and don't have the money (or lack of sense) to buy a seat on Mars One, go buy Kerbal Space Program.

author: {'steamid': '76561198054350781', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 1917, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1522, 'last_played': 1464684769}
review: T.O.M would have to be one of the most intelligent games Steam has to offer.. the Experience itself is jaw droppingly brilliant from its rich photorealistic graphics to the diversity of missions & new multiplayer makes it even more appealing. It takes some geting used to the Rover controls and getting around in general as this is not your typical "game" but a realistic impression on heading a mission to Mars..   Strap in & get ready for one awesome experience that is not only a sim.. but a learning experience in all things related to previous missions to the Red Planet..

author: {'steamid': '76561198065052712', 'num_games_owned': 98, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 2712, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2153, 'last_played': 1546355376}
review:
Il secondo Take On.
Massimo realismo senza compromessi, in lento ma inesorabile sviluppo, grafica ben ottimizzata e spettacolarmente bella, recente pubblicazione del multigiocatore indipendente da Gamespy ed un futuro ancora tutto da costruire.
Take On Mars  ha intenzione di definire nuovi standard per il realismo e la simulazione, proponendo inoltre un tema ed uno scenario fin'ora mai immaginati.
Un simulatore verosimile e realistico per l'esplorazione di Marte, e quindi molto immersivo e coinvolgente; dedicato ovviamente ad un pubblico non molto vasto, ma composto da veri appassionati di scienza ed allo stesso tempo di videogiochi.
Ancora la Bohemia Interactive ci stupisce proponendosi come madre del realismo e della plausibilità.

review:
Wo ist das Spiel?

Im Ernst, die Engine ist nett anzusehen, die Features sind auch ganz nett, aber: wo ist das Spiel? Es gibt stumpf keins. Keine Herausforderung, keine Schwierigkeit, kein Spielraum, um etwas richtig oder falsch zu machen, nicht einmal Glück.

author: {'steamid': '76561198062427148', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 218, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 76, 'last_played': 1431164403}

author: {'steamid': '76561197992328443', 'num_games_owned': 1505, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 8171, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2543, 'last_played': 1641052623}
review:
I don't even have the words to describe how much I like this game...
Or, you know, "game". Not sure if the word applies, but I'm going to use it anyway.

Here's what you do: Send stuff to mars. On mars, you control stuff like the wheels on rovers, various cameras and scientific equipment etc. Everything is very slow-paced. You have specific missions that tell you to photograph certain features, test the atmosphere at a specific locations, etc. There are no enemies. There is very little challenge... Except it reuires a very specific type of mind to enjoy spending half an hour driving a tiny rover a few hundre meters of more or less featureless desert to take a few photographs, maybe a soil sample, then move on.

Lately, more challenges have been added, which I really like. The tech tree wasn't there when I first began playing, and I enjoy trying to figure out what to research next in order to unlock the next batch of missions. It also feels like money is a bit tighter, which means a bit of budgeting and making sure you don't overextend. The vehicles run out of juice earlier as well, which means there's some challenge in trying to get as much use from each rover as possible, completing several missions before it gives up.

Another kind of challenging thing is how easily things break. I've completed several missions with rovers that are missing two or more wheels (using well-known workarounds such as driving backwards)...

The graphics are top notch aside from a few quirks (sometimes rocks still hover slightly above the landscape...)

All in all an incredibly rewarding experience to the patient-minded who want a break from pvp and rts and fps...

author: {'steamid': '76561198065598901', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 1149, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1143, 'last_played': 1446783313}
review: As many others have said, this title has a ton of potential. That being said, as it stands right now it is a fairly fun experience but it's pretty obvious that it needs to be "finished" and polished. I think that as far as sims are concerned, this game provides the best real to life experience of what it would be like to be on Mars (via robot, rover, or even as an astronaut). Give it time and I'm sure anyone who plays it will enjoy it!

author: {'steamid': '76561198065812356', 'num_games_owned': 318, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 2677, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1198, 'last_played': 1485061660}
review: This game is relaxing, and supplies a atmospheric landscape to travel around in. this game can become fustrating though when the funding is too low and there is no other way to get money than restart.

author: {'steamid': '76561197961033346', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 1286, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 799, 'last_played': 1625007868}
review:
Definitely a Work In Progress. Steep learning curve because most of the tutorials aren't done. SAVE FREQUENTLY. The Tech Tree is frustrating in that none of the components are explained well enough for you to know where the components will go and what other components are required for them to function (I guess if you build these IRL you might know already), so you end up spending huge chunks of your budget only to find out you've researched the wrong techs. *Thus ends the negatives*

This will be a great Sim once it's completed! In the same vein as Kerbal, only the Realistic Time setting makes it as life-like as possible. Going to be another great Sim from Bohemia.

author: {'steamid': '76561198075785078', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 2894, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1976, 'last_played': 1658263768}

author: {'steamid': '76561198028583837', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 3268, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3181, 'last_played': 1591151677}
review:
first  is too restrictive.   we cant build vehicles from parts  we must use nasa methods   which extreemly limits the play diversity  
while the environment is very mars like   exploring or gathering science is also  scripted and repetitive.  mission "press the button"  player  "presses the button"     so the devs are micromanaging the players right now    so the game/simulation needs more freedom and diversity      if the player is interested in a specific rock formation  they can go look at it but game wise its pointless. 

they need to add mini rovers,    orbiters,   drones,   balloons   ground penetrating landers   and as many different experiments as they can think up       how about experiment that works in cooperation with other landers like 3D imagery  or  seismic experiment  where several craft place seismometers on the ground,, then another lander launches out  explosive probes  that land on the surface and detonate  and the landers collect the results?  

how about telescopes?   how about weather guages that actually work and tell us how fast the wind is moving 

how about some ways for players to interact with systems  on board their craft possibly even improve or repair them  or  bypass damage  or adjust power levels 

how about some experiments that can serve additional science    such as radio signals  being used to determine atmosphere depth or planet width simply by  the signal strength or drop out.

author: {'steamid': '76561198032356374', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1221, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 604, 'last_played': 1500608358}
review:
I'm really enjoying this simulation. 

I agree with other post though, wish the analysis was a little faster. And sometimes the tumbling probes can't go on a little too long. I do like that you can double click when going to the Lab to avoid the cleanroom but it would be even nicer if it took you directly there instead to another screen where you have to double-click again to get to it. That's probably being picky though.

I have no idea what the triangles mean on screen when landing but to be fair I haven't read a lot about the game so far. 

Thanks to all that have posted guides. I had to restart the game because I researched everything and lost all my money.
They are very helpful figuring stuff out. There's still a lot I don't understand but again, I just jumped into the game without reading much.

It's a lot of fun for me and the type of simulation I really enjoy. Looking forward to the updates!

author: {'steamid': '76561198069071379', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1062, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1060, 'last_played': 1416926206}
review:
最近火星入植できるようになったが、それでも地味。ただただ地味。
だがこの地味さこそが宇宙開発気分を盛り上げているのは紛れもない事実なのだ。

PVを見ればわかるが、簡単に言えば「火星(+小惑星)探査シミュ」
基本は「探査機打ち上げ→探査目標を達成→報酬で技術ツリーを進める」の繰り返し。ただ、資金繰りは中々シビア。
作りたい探査機を選べば必要な技術がハイライトされるのでまずはライトランダー(探査プラットフォーム)から作ろう。

最初は投げっぱなし探査機のプローブぐらいしか打ち上げできないが、技術ツリーを進めれば火星だけでなく小惑星の探査機なんかも作れてしまう。気分ははやぶさ。
ただ、この小惑星探査は激ムズ。ちょっとジェットをふかしただけで探査機はグルングルン回り、慎重に動かしても小惑星着陸は中々出来ない。だがそれがイイ。(追記：この強すぎる慣性はオプションでなくすことが出来るようだ。)

編成次第では一台のローバー(自走探査機)で同じ地域のミッションを幾つもこなすことができるが、移動が如何せん遅いので、離れた所にあるミッションでは移動だけで20分も30分もかかる。ここはARMAに通じるものがあるかもしれない。
火星は障害物が少ないので自動操縦で放置して進ませてもいいのだが、油断してると大岩にぶつかって車載機器が破損してたりする。
大金払って開発し、送り込んだ探査機に着地の衝撃で駆動系エラーが出たりもする。
イライラするかもしれないが、惑星探査とはそういうものだと割りきって、むしろその不便さを楽しむのがこのTake On Marsというゲームなのかもしれない。

ビジュアルは地味、システムは硬派でUIは使いづらい。果てしない時間を注ぎながらも、エラーを吐き一定時間毎に右駆動系が止まる探査機を駆るのが止められないのは無限に広がる大宇宙への憧れからなのか？

入植パートはあまり触れていないので割愛するが、殺風景な火星を骨の髄までしゃぶり尽くしたい人や、探査機オペレーターになりたい人、単調な作業を通じて忍耐力を高めたい人は買ってみよう。

author: {'steamid': '76561198004604990', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 3615, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1393, 'last_played': 1528901832}
review:
Was soll man schon groß über so ein Spiel schreiben? 

Es ist genial und macht (mich zumindest) extrem süchtig. 
Wenn man sich erst einmal hineingefitzt hat (hat bei mir einen Sonntag gedauert), dann macht es unglaublich viel Spaß. Anfangs hat man auch das Gefühl, dass man regelrecht von diesem Spiel erschlagen wird, aber je mehr man spielt, desto überschaubarer und "suchtender" wird dieses Spiel.

Man fängt mit ein paar Sonden an, die einfach landen und liegen bleiben. Im Navigationsfenster kann man sich zudem die aktuelle Mission anzeigen lassen und diese gegebenenfalls filtern. So hat man einen besseren Überblick und kann sich die Navipunkte nach: Nähe, weiter weg oder unendlich, anzeigen lassen. Wenn man jetzt noch den Filter einstellt, dass man nur die Missionspunkte anzeigen lässt, am besten noch auf "nah", dann fährt man (wenn man dann einen Rover hat) die Punkte einfach ab und hat die Mission abgeschlossen. 

Die Arbeiten der Sonden und Rover sind genau die, die man aus den ganzen Dokus und Büchern kennt. Umgebung analysieren, und da gibt es ja wirklich jede Menge und ist natürlich von den Fahrzeugen abhängig.

Alles in allem, ist es einfach ein grandioses Spiel. Ich kann es jedem Astronomie-Interessierten nur empfehlen.

Bugs:

Hatte bis jetzt erst zwei Aussetzer, die Sonde landete ins bodenlose, könnte eine Jupiter Simulation gewesen sein ;)

Fazit:

Für ein "Early Access-Spiel", ist es spielbarer als manch AAA Titel.

author: {'steamid': '76561198049888061', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 9488, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1461, 'last_played': 1601805656}

author: {'steamid': '76561197988188501', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 44, 'playtime_forever': 312, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 71, 'last_played': 1495406438}

author: {'steamid': '76561197960961580', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 63, 'playtime_forever': 601, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 587, 'last_played': 1416970345}
review:
I'm not sure.  I want to like Take On Mars, but overall I don't find it a very engaging game.

TOM wants you to play the game its way, or the highway.  My first play through and I spent all of my money to build a super-lander.  It had a robot arm, soil scoop, atmosphere sensors, the works.  I managed to get it down on the ground and thought to myself: "Whoo!  Let's do some SCIENCE!"  And then the game said, "Yay, you explored this region!  Now do it some more, elsewhere!"  Wait.  What?

I wasn't able to use my robot arm or soil scoop.  My atmosphere sensor was useless.  The game had intended only for me to complete a set of explore-the-area objectives before it would unlock the next set.  I realized then that Bohemia Interactive had a much different idea of SCIENCE! than I did.  To me, spending my wad on an uber-science craft made sense.  Cram as much science as you can in a single big-budget mission so you can unlock more technology.   But I was thinking like a scientist, not as a game player.

And that's where TOM lost me.  The game wants me to play it like a game.  I was expecting a simulator.  For something that bills itself as a simulator, I found this really disappointing.

Science tasks earn me money, and I spend that money to research better science-making gear.   This system feels hap-hazard and slapped together.  Why not have a separate budget versus "science points" (much like in Kerbal Space Program)?  Why is the science objective-based instead of having "wells of science fact" that are tapped and eventually exhausted (again, like KSP)?

In fact, playing this game just made me want to play KSP instead.  Which is a real pity, because TOM looks great and it could be a real contender for introducing people to the act of managing a space program and how extraterrestial science works.

I restarted my game and played it The Right Way and was able to upgrade to rovers.  I was excited at first, because I thought this was a chance to do something interesting.  Only to realize that "interesting" meant holding down the "W" key for hours on end, driving a slow rover across the Martian surface.  And this is where TOM completely lost me.  Suddenly, it wanted to act like a realistic simulator -- Oh you have to DRIVE AROUND to find interesting science!  In realtime!  With no automatic navigation system!

At that point, I just stopped playing.  I haven't bothered to unlock the next set of objectives, and have yet to set a human down on the surface of Mars in TOM, and that's a real pity.

Oh well, at least my science base on Duna is thriving...

author: {'steamid': '76561197970562487', 'num_games_owned': 799, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 1379, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1377, 'last_played': 1521022452}
review: This is an awesome game if you are at all into space exploration and science. Its extreamly atmosphereic and really great if you need a game to chill out to. I will say though that there can be long stretches of time where you are doing nothing but holding down that w button if you are trying to be as effciant and use a rover for more that one set of missions. Still I love it a lot and its cool to wander around a planet entirly enhabited by robots. That is untill you put people on it!

author: {'steamid': '76561198086034207', 'num_games_owned': 638, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 539, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 363, 'last_played': 1475767863}
review:
Review:

Wenn man sich erstmal die Seite des Spiels ansieht,denkt man das es einfach nur ein kleiner Simulator ist wo man zum Spaß mal Rover wie "Spirit","Opportunity" oder "Curiosity" steuern kann.Denkste.Da steckt auch schon was dahinter,zum Beispiel kann man nicht einfach all sein Geld nach dem Zufallsprinzip in den Forschungsbaum investieren ohne dann Leer dazustehen,staatliche Fördergelder gibts da nicht.Man wird dafür bezahlt Wissenschaftliche Funde hervorzubringen,zu anfangs kleinere Dinge wie den Mars kartografieren,dann später schickt man schon (stolz) seine erste Sonde,mit Steinprobenmessgerät los wenn man das nötige kleingeld hat,darf es auch ein Rover sein.Solche missionen bringen mehr Geld.Damit wäre man auch bei dem Thema,wer keine lust darauf hat einen Mini-Finanzsimulator in Take on Mars mitzunehmen kann einfach die Szenarien spielen .

Alles in allem ein gutes Spiel mit sehr viel Potential,ich kann es nur weiterempfehlen.

10/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198077390376', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 1141, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 939, 'last_played': 1425923297}

author: {'steamid': '76561197979895454', 'num_games_owned': 799, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 9251, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1588, 'last_played': 1608276753}
review: This game had great potential, but the devs stop giving a crap after they shifted focus on DayZ and the P2W game Vigor. I asked them on twitter if they plan to update the game and they claim it's finished. This is a giant lie. The game is full of bugs that would normally be removed in a finished product, but as this is Bohemia Interactive they said "fudge it leave them in and lets move on to making easy money because we're lazy". Do not buy this game even if it's on sale as it'll be a huge waste of your time when you find out how unfinished this game is. The BF3 beta was more finished than this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198033738760', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 4034, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 172, 'last_played': 1521489869}
review:
Take On Mars ist eine sehr gut gemachte, umfangreiche Simulation.

TOM ist leider überhaupt nicht anfängerfreundlich. Man wird nach einem kurzen Einführungslevel (KEIN Tutorial) gleich ins kalte Wasser geworfen, außer ein paar Videos darüber, wo man was findet, ist leider nichts erklärt.
Alleingelassen startet man eine Mission, man findet raus: die Start-Probe  kann gar nix. Man hat Geld verschwendet.
Also erstmal n bisschen Tech researchen bevor man irgendwas tut.
Ist man endllich gelandet, so muss man sich mit der schwierigen und umständlichen Steuerung herumschlagen. Auch wenn das vlt. gewollt ist, nerven tuts trotzdem.
Alles in allem ist TOM aber ein schönes Spiel und empfehlenswert

author: {'steamid': '76561198038986109', 'num_games_owned': 27, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 74, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 52, 'last_played': 1422814636}

Not a very nice feeling at all, though the game is in development, but no money should be taken from this kind of immature product! This game should be in free beta for testing. 

Cheers.

author: {'steamid': '76561197988485371', 'num_games_owned': 4379, 'num_reviews': 221, 'playtime_forever': 1364, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 67, 'last_played': 1677234673}
review:
Ein geniales Spiel. Oder eher Simulation ? Ich weiß nicht. Wer Spiele wie Take on Helicopters oder Lunar Flight mag und auf einen hohen Realismusgrad steht findet hier sein persönliches Excalibur.

Das Spiel ist etappenweise schwerer als ein Zementlaster, jedoch nie unfair. 

Eine gigantische Auswahl an Kameras an verschiedenen Rovern sind zum einen ein "cooles" Gadget, jedoch auch notwendig um die Gefährte milimeter genau an bestimmte Orte zu bugsieren.

Der Sound ist okay. Nichts besonderes.

Anders die Grafik. Die weitsicht in der man meist nur die flache Marsoberfläche sieht, von Steinen gespickt, lässt ein komisches Gefühl aufkommen. Man sitzt nicht in dem Rover drin, der elektrische Gefährte ist alleine auf dem Mars, jedoch fühlt man sich immer mittendrin und irgendwie alleingelassen in dieser trostlosen Landschaft. - Im positiven Sinne !

Kann das Spiel jedem Weltraumbegeistertem nur empfehlen !

author: {'steamid': '76561198000264131', 'num_games_owned': 1679, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 671, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 377, 'last_played': 1455999406}
review:
Už sakra dost těch armád! … už dost válek! … pojďme zakopat válečnou sekyru a přidejme se na stranu vědy ( Poslední slova mírumilovného člověka než mu hruď protkal bajonet ) … a teď tohle prohlašuje Bohemia Interactive a daří se jí? .. no zatím do zad nedostala ničím .. ani pohlavek zajímavé? … čím to? .. asi tím jak dobře jí de simulace a prostě tohle je sakra povedený kousek .. neberte mě špatně (Nejsem Militarista i když se na válku rád koukám) … ale tohle vypadá jak stejně dobrý počin né-li ještě zábavnější jak Arma III .. samozřejmě hrušky a jablka! Ale co s tím když jsou od samého výrobce? … koupíte si oba a oba chutnají skvěle a tohle je přesně případ Take on Mars který na první pohled vypadá dost podivně, nepřehledně a nudně … ale opak je pravdou pokud vás aspoň trošku zajímá věda nebo vesmír (Ahoj Kerbale) tak si tohle užijete .. zde nestavíte rakety ale nýbrž vesmírné sondy a vozítka které zkoumají povrch rudé planety Mars … jednoduše jste vedoucí vesmírného programu jehož úkolem je zkoumat nové technologie a zjistit o rudé planetě cokoliv co vám investoři zadají a pokud to splníte dostanete plus do kapsy z čehož můžete zkoumat dál a funguje to skvěle .. ale ještě líp tu funguje to že hra má možnost REAL – TIME což vidím u hry poprvé a sakra se mi ta možnost líbí i když sem ji nevyužil a podstata je taková že si místo herního času nastavíte ten normální jako v reálném životě … dáte výzkum, vyšlete sondu a mezitím jdete do práce a za ten čas už snad vše je .. prostě hrajete tu na reálný čas a jediný způsob jak tohle posunout je jít do postele nebo hrát jinou hru nebo třeba jen čumět do monitoru … taky je možnost v mezi čase hrát staré arkádové hry co jsou zabudované přímo ve hře .. každopádně hra je skvělý počin a Venuše … eeech myslím Lidi co tohle zplodily můžou být na svůj počin hrdí. Ale stále Early Acess.

Překvapení.
+Pokud máte rádi vědu v jádru zábava ale není to pro každého furt je to „simulace“ pozor na to!
+Hodně možností jak zkoumat.
+Real-Time možnost.

Zklamaní.
-Grafické Chybky.
-Těžké se naučit.
-Musíte si dávat pozor jak utrácíte jiným způsobem než zkoumáním grant získat nelze.

9/10 –až hra vyjde pouvažuju zda dát bodík plus nebo mínus.

Verdikt – Místo bajonetu do zad na Bohemku hoďte pytlík peněz. 

Koupit? – Klidně i za plnou cenu, Ve slevě na 99% ano.

Můj Web - http://bohuslavj.wix.com/outplayed

author: {'steamid': '76561198085137071', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 702, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 432, 'last_played': 1461498223}

author: {'steamid': '76561197986227109', 'num_games_owned': 615, 'num_reviews': 46, 'playtime_forever': 650, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 607, 'last_played': 1486792828}
review:
Mám za sebou takovéto koštování hry a jejích funkcí.
Hra má potenciál a rozhodně tu je o co stát.
Z joystickem je to o to větší zábava, když si doslova s tím roverem hrajete.

Kampaň je prozatím dost limitovaná unifikovaným postupem, kde rozpočet je natolik nekompromisní, že hráč může jít vývojovým stromem defakto jen jedinou cestou (což ale odráží realitu, nic víc).
Hráči, kteří hledají více svobody a více volovin by se měli poohlédnout po Kerbal Space Program.

Tak jako tak: těším se na další obsah a více z lidské posádky! :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198013937269', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 27, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 27, 'last_played': 1400411444}
review: No tutorial thats worth much, confusing and slow UI. A frustrating game that showed alot of promise....i wish i could get a refund.

author: {'steamid': '76561198034006844', 'num_games_owned': 419, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 2671, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 444, 'last_played': 1613683999}
review:
Super jeu du "grand" Bohemian Interactive ! Plongez au coeur de la recherche en plein sur La Planète Rouge ! Même si le jeu n'est terminé, il y a le temps de jouer en "Real Time" du mode carrière. 

Vivement de nouvelle MàJ ;)

author: {'steamid': '76561198061288326', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 2035, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2035, 'last_played': 1443998081}
review: If you are a Space geek like I am, you will likely enjoy this game at any and every stage of development. If you are thinking about persuing a career in space exploration or aerospace engineering, you will likely enjoy this game. That said, it is a very slow game. I have read through entire books while driving from one place to another. The simulation of tools and cameras is very good and the game excels in that respect.  However, many features are not implemented yet but it is getting better and more complete. I highly recommend playing with a joystick as opposed to a controller. Also, because it is a simulation for an activity that involves sitting at a desk for the part you are playing, it takes a little role playing to get the very most out of it. Get a cup of coffee and a book or two and pretend you're working at JPL driving a real rover. It makes it a much more enjoyable experience, just don't break off any wheels while you're reading. That would not be good for your (pretend) career.

author: {'steamid': '76561198013855884', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 1783, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1783, 'last_played': 1399751602}
review:
Hart! Steile Lernkurve! Frustrationstoleranz unabdingbar... aber macht dennoch ungeheuer Laune!

05.Mai 2014 (Early Alpha Phase)
Spielrunde 1: Klasse den Mars erkunden! Aber vorher steht wohl mühselige Arbeit.... mit kleinen, nicht steuerbaren Drohnen (Probe) soll ich die erste Schritte auf meiner Erkundung machen. Damit verdiene ich mein mageres Einkommen, das ich in die Erforschung weiterer Technologien stecken sollte, damit ich mehr Forschungsaufträge bekomme.

Grafisch fühle ich mich wie in den 60ern: meine unerentwickelten Kamerase liefern grieselige schwarz-weiß Bilder. Winde und Stürme erschweren nicht nur meine Sicht, nein, sie treiben auch meine Sonden vom eigentlichen Zielort ab. Es ist mühsam und aufwändig Geld zu verdienen. Die Abläufe wiederholen sich - aber egal: was tut man nicht Alles für die Wissenschaft. Ich investriere in bessere Kameras und verfeinere die, bis zu hochauflösenden Aufnahmen. Das bringt mir nicht wirklich was - und: das Geld geht mir aus, neue Missionen bekomme ich auch nicht. Mist. Alles nochmal vonm vorne?

Spielrunde 2: Diesmal mache ich es besser! Als erstes wird in dem überwiegend englischsprachigen Forum mal nachgelesen. Ups - ok - da habe ich wohl den einen und anderen Fehler gemacht. Völlig falsch erforscht das Ganze. Aha - ich muss mich stärker an den Missionen und den dafür benötigten Geräten orientieren. OK. Los gehts. ABER zunächst schalte ich mal diese nervige Musik ab, nee, die bringt es gar nicht - vielleicht doch mal den Soundtrack aus dem "Workshop" einbinden?

Ich beginne geduldig. Setze meine Sonden besser, sammle das Geld und orientiere mich an den Missionen. Bodenproben mit einem "Lander" das soll es sein. Ok. Geld habe ich ja jetzt und forsche tapfer vor mich hin. Ich klicke im "Techtree" brav auf der linken Seite und hangle mich dann rechts durch die zu erforschenden (erwerbenden) Module, die zum Glück ja blau markiert sind. Endlich kann ich mit den "Landern" spielen - verzichte sogar auf "meine Kameras", aber beschließe auch einen größeren Lander in Auftrag zugeben (Forschung) - das allerdings kostet mich letztendlich soviel Geld, dass ich schon wieder keine neuen Missionen bekomme. Ach - ich hatte besser den "Robotic Arm" erforscht? Ups - ich hätte es ja wissen müssen. Habe ich irgendwie übersehen. Kann einem das nicht Einer deutlicher sagen.... Öhm: nein, das rudimentäre Tutorial zu Spielstart bringt diesbezüglich nichts. Und meine angestellten Wissenschaftler sagen auch nichts. Blubb.

Spielrunde 3:
Ich passe besser auf - ich spare mein Geld. Ich spiele ganz vorsichtig. Das Forenlesen wird mein ständiger Begleiter - leider verstehe ich nur die Hälfte und denke manchmal, meine "Forenmitglieder" wissen es auch nicht besser. Einige haben ähnliche Probleme. Ach - habe ich schon gesagt, dass ich demnächst wieder ruiniert bin? Ich wollte unbedingt den Asteroidengürtel erforschen (Freischalten kostet 500) Dazu brauche ich dann aber auch eine Zero-G-Probe mit Schnickschnack und Sonderausstattung, die ich mir nicht mehr leisten kann - weil... ihr wisst schon: es ist echt hart auf dem Mars und in der Wissenschaft sein Geld zu verdienen. Ich sehe die vierte Spielrunde schon winken ;-)

Nicht befasst habe ich mich mit den verlockenden vorgefertigen Szenarien, die mir auch erlauben würde eine bemannte Mission oder auch die originale Pathfinder-Mission nach- bzw. mitzuerleben. Nein, werde ich so schnell nicht. Ich werde es diesem Spiel schon zeigen. Ich bekomme das hin. Gebt mir nur noch einen weiteren Versuch und ich werde das managen.

Wäre doch gelacht wenn ich an der sehr gut simulierten Realität der Weltraumforschung scheitere! Ha!

Ach, wusstet ihr schon, dass 1 SOL (ein Marstag): 24 Stunden 39 Minuten und 35.244 Sekunden lang ist?

author: {'steamid': '76561198017756928', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 50, 'playtime_forever': 684, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 681, 'last_played': 1523732426}
review:
This was a positive review, but I no longer feel that way. Ammended review:

It's been in Early Access for (literally) years now. At some point it becomes an excuse for developers to never finish something, or always be able to promise "more features in the future" - which is what's happened here. 

I was severely disappointed several months ago when I realized they no longer cared about science results and testing of Mars and started focusing on the multiplayer aspect, but I know teenagers/gamers are the target audience on Steam, so I wasn't completely surprised by the shift. However, that was nearly a year ago. In that time, nothing has changed in the single-player "science" campaign at all. It's been the same thing since I bought the game years ago. I really, really wanted to like this game, but it's just not meant to be. I mean, how long can you call something "beta", yet make money from it, and get away with it?

If Bohemia can own up to the failures and shortcomings and put some TLC (ie. patching, time, development, and customer concern awareness) back into this, I might switch back to a positive review. But that is very doubtful at this point. They've run out of time for me.

author: {'steamid': '76561198063843977', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 176, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 151, 'last_played': 1428774490}
review: I bought this game and played it for 2 hours straight. All I was doing was launching probes at Mars but knowing that everything I was seeing in game was rendered off topographic maps of the area and craters is astonishing. So much detail has been put into this game that it is worth your $17 alone. Now this game isn't for everyone and I am a HUGE geek when it comes to games like this but just the fact that I am taking an object with such in-depth attention to detail is just what makes the game. I cannot recommend this game enough if you have ever thought about the colonization of another planet or if you are just a curious science teaching working on a Astronomy lesson, this is a great way to learn more and more about the celestial bodies around us and a more intriguing way of taking the colonization into your own hands.

author: {'steamid': '76561197988283844', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 1869, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 493, 'last_played': 1492517209}

author: {'steamid': '76561197984800915', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 108, 'playtime_forever': 6842, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3079, 'last_played': 1690391336}
review:
"My God, it's full of stars!"
I have had this game since the early versions and even then it felt like a shop ready product and not early access, and the new updates have just felt like free DLC.
The screen shots tell the story of the graphics, they are awesome, and the whole game looks like that.
The realism is, well I've never sent a probe to Mars, but it feels pretty bleeding real to me. And the realism is the key to your enjoyment of this title. 

If you want fast paced action on a future Mars then move along (I've seen posts saying it's boring, pah!).

If you're like me and absorb yourself into a sim about the current exploration of Mars, with all the slow analysis of rocks and atmosphere and the chance to take photos that look very similar to NASA pics that comes with that then buy this game, clear about a month in your schedule and prepare for a real, scientific and indepth exploration of our solar cousin.

As real as it gets. Stunning sim. 11/10.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993709617', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 9754, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7395, 'last_played': 1680820401}
review:
Can't fault this game in any way really.
It does exactly what it says on the tin and more besides.
With the manned mission coming, it shows nothing but bigger and better things on the horizon.
And the best thing of all is that I can honestly say this has been the best experience of early access development I have encountered ever.
Mostly it's just an occasional update. Sometimes it's a game released as a tech demo and then the devs vanish with your cash. Other times they release a couple of tiny updates that do nothing much, then call the game finished.
These guys have been incredible, with a huge amount of updates, constant feedback on the forums, both here and the bohemia forums.
I have even had them add me as a friend, ask for my input personally, and seen my suggestions added within a day.
I have had them reply to a problem I was having, email my save file to one of them (Dram, he is just the best, seriously, great developer for early access, he is into helping the community all the time), and had a patch released that fixes a problem that only I was having. He did that within 2 hours of me posting the topic on the steam forum.
As for the game. If you have any interest in this kind of thing, then this is for you. It does exactly what you would expect, and it does it in such a way as to make you feel like you work for NASA, without having to learn all about rocket science and such to do so.
This alongside kerbal space program show exactly how this kind of game is great for early access, when they have the right developer.
I can't fault this game at all.
The only thing is that I am itching for release now, to see how the finished product turns out. But with all the new things they keep announcing, it looks likely to be in early access for a while.
But seeing as the early access experience here has been almost as enjoyable as the game itself, I don't see that as a terrible thing. I have been made to feel important, an integral part of the evolution of the game, right from the start. And their enthusiasm hasn't waned at all.
Buy it, buy it now, even if just to support early access done right.

author: {'steamid': '76561198012120340', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 119, 'playtime_forever': 703, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 477, 'last_played': 1447799980}

author: {'steamid': '76561197990258228', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 47, 'playtime_forever': 2327, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2327, 'last_played': 1542044035}
review:
I have over 250 games in my Steam library. Out of all 250 this is the only game I can confidently say this in a review for:

DON'T BUY THIS!!

It's a Bohemia game, so the engine is awful. On top of that the development was sloppy (I watched its development for years in early access) and the content is so bland, you'll probably have more fun if you spent your money on a real life Lego set.

For multiplayer to work properly you'll need a mod for the game that fixes multiplayer bugs left by the developers. Once you've done that, you need to mod in content for the game because, as mentioned above, there's little in the way of content.

Even if you do all that you'll struggle to make this worth the $27 price tag. It worth $10 at most, I'd say, and I wouldn't even suggest buying it on sale.

Once again let me put it this way: This is the only game out of all the games I have that I 100% would never recommend someone to buy. Not because I didn't enjoy it, but because it is literally the worst game in my (at this time) 250 title library.

author: {'steamid': '76561198041885520', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 47, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 40, 'last_played': 1401046948}
review:
Would not suggest until improved.

The Game jumps you into a scenario with no guidence or tutorial, you only control the motion-sickness-inducing camera and a rover you have no knowledge of and have no feedback of its existance unless you manage to get lucky and guess the key for an external view. 
After that it contiunes assuming you know the entire game inside out and lets you try to figure out the cryptic controls and buttons, having to wait though really long cutscenes with GPU-Melting graphics while the camera does its best to convey the feeling of being in a small dingy during a typhoon.

Even on minimal settings you'll get less than 30fps unless you have a pair of Titans, the menus are terrible and extremely hard to navigate due to combined mouse-lag and mouse accelation.


At the end of the day; wouldn't buy yet. Could be great with some proper menus though.

author: {'steamid': '76561198033262276', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 179, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 179, 'last_played': 1375454888}
review:
Hello Gentlemen, 

Just got Take On Mars by Bohemia Interactive, the early access is available for download on steam. Downloaded it, installed it and double clicked on play. Straight to the options menu and run in windowed mode and then changed my mind and put it back to full screen mode. The first screen that greets you is the Take On Mars menu with the usual game options and a spinning depiction of planet Mars. You can hold down the LMB and spin the planet around and see cool sounding names like - Syrtis Major and Elysium Planitia. A few clicks and the initial tutorial loads up.  Clicked on Real World Time and eventually I make my way to the Lab and Construction Building. Found myself pressing the 'Test Vehicle' panel & see the lander. I see different views and instruments, You see (not manipulate) the outside world. My first test ship wobbled like crazy and the wide angle and telephoto view quality, looked like they had purchased the same cameras used in the Blair Witch project. Maybe it's an early alpha thing? I think Bohemia are simulating the quality of video/pictures sent from Mars back to Earth -- lossy and crap. Like any man on the planet who has never read an instruction manual since making 1/32 Airfix models, I end up pressing every single key to see what screens pop up. Oooh... aaarghhh... what does that do... oohhh.... Esc key goes to Main Menu.  Yawn and fast forwarded to the Launch vehicle 13mins 39secs. Look around the crater for about six or seven minutes and then stumble on the list of tasks required to be completed in this particular mission.

After pressing every key again, q,w,e,r,t,y,,,,,. I find myself at the Capture Gas stage. oooh... aarghhhh.... Click on Capture Gas. Yay! DO NOT MOVE INSTRUMENT in flashing red text. First you capture the gas, then you analyse gas. (Insert Fart Joke) This is one of the Major Tasks completed at the initial first assignment Victoria Crater. Your initial foray in the Victoria Crater teaches you Mars atmospheric pressure differences compared to Earth and also the composition percentages of CO2, N & Ar (I knew learning the first twenty elements of the periodic table would be useful in my lifetime.. thanks to my grade 10 science teacher Mr Clewett). Once you complete a mission, you also get access to New Tech Levels and various vehicle and instruments at tech level 2 become available.  And I got a steam achievement unlocked "It's All About the Science" I then read the rest of the Mission task and see there is another minor task, a photo opportunity requirement.

The light bulb dims and I figure out that mission tasks are comprised of Major task and Minor tasks. Each successful completion of Major & Minor tasks during a mission will allow you access to higher level tech and more cash to spend on stuff. In the Early Access version, I can see some instruments have power levels and charge / drain rates and I guess that there would be that certain tasks that require balancing energy usage from your chemical batteries before they are depleted in the later missions. Don't know yet if there are ways to recharge. It's interesting but not for everyone. Interesting enough I had the game freeze on me twice and waited and waited and waited.... before the three finger salute Ctrl+Alt+Del restarted the game.

My initial thoughts coming from a Flight Sim enthusiast...... Well just like there are people that are vegetarians and there are people who like a medium rare wagyu rump with a side of hand cut fries, mushrooms swimming in a red wine jus. Take On Mars just doesn't have enough meat to satisfy me. Do your own due diligence and make an informed decision. Read the reviews, watch other videos and then make a purchase or not decision. I 'm not satisfied. If I want a space sim, Kerbal Space Program has that creativity streak that Take On Mars doesn't. Would I play Take On Mars often? Only if my Warthog HOTAS was stolen, and every other computer game I owned was destroyed and it was raining outside and it was a Saturday in June. Aside from that, sure I will play it.

Another thing, what is early access, an alpha, beta or in-between? Call it what it is - an Alpha....

Thanks go to my grade 10 Science teacher Mr Clewett -- You were right, I would use the knowledge of the first twenty elements in the periodic table in my life time. :)

Score: 2/10

author: {'steamid': '76561197968549943', 'num_games_owned': 1461, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 1664, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 995, 'last_played': 1615093030}
review:
An interesting "game" so far.   There is a ton of potential here and I look forward to what the developers have in store.   This is a hard core sim, make no mistake about it. 

You start with a small sum of money and essentially have to launch probes and gather data.  You can research upgrades so you can create better probes and eventually rovers.  It is slow going,. and you wil invest a lot of time just to get the payoff of meeting the mission goals.  That payoff is well worth it!

You will question yourself and make mistakes.  It can be a frustrating experience to build what you feel is an excellent rover for a mission, only to have it blown over when you make the mistake of landing in an area with hurricane force winds.  Ouch!  But you end up going back for more because you want to get it right.

I have been playing with this the past few days and am hooked.  My 7 year old loves driving the rovers around and if anything, it has opened his mind to asking a million questions about Mars and space exploration.  That is a huge win and worth the cost alone for me.
